transcripts.text: Let's go ahead and go to our next call.  This is Steven in Michigan.  Hey, Steven, you're on the air.  What's up?
Hey, Dan.  How's it going?
Going all right, man.  How are you?
Doing well.  Cool, cool.  How are you, Dave?
Hey, Steven.  Good to talk to you, man.  All right.
So this is my one note I have here.  It says new chronology.  Human history is only a thousand years old.
Yeah, have you guys ever heard of that?
You know, I think I've heard of this before.
We're learning new stuff today.
I swore I've read something like this before.  It's like this idea that a lot of human history has kind of been constructed, but I can't remember the reasons why or any of the details.

Yeah, it's really interesting.  just personally i've been going through it for the last couple years.  uh i decided to pick it because i thought it had some merit to it but at the same time i was studying logic and trying to find something to test it on.  and um this is.  it's a huge thing.  it's called from yinka's new chronology and it's a empirical statistical analysis of narrative materials.  and um basically it just accounts for a lot of weird issues and whatnot in the history books and um.  so it's kind of interesting just to go through and just going back on it.  myself i've i'm pretty i was familiar with world history to a degree you know prior to looking into it and uh then looking back on it all i kind of wonder you know how do we know about this type of stuff?  and so i guess um One of the main things is textual, like the manuscripts and stuff, tablets and whatnot.  Like how do we actually know what happened in history?  It's pretty weird stuff, but I don't know.
Yeah, break this down for me.  How do we get to that?  it's only 1,000 years old?  Where does that number come from?

So pretty much what the theory is.  summarized, this is going to be really simple.  It's a complex theory, but there's a few tools that were developed to analyze narrative materials.  And the summary of it all is basically that there's the Greco-Roman timeline, which is the backbone to history timeline.  Pretty much that was developed around the 15th to 16th centuries.  Following that, the next two major studies were Egyptian studies and Indian studies that came out of that and into the Near East and Asiatic studies spawning out of there.  But pretty much it's based off of this Greek-Roman timeline.  And it's really heavily based around the Byzantine structure and pretty much when you analyze the information that we have, there are parallels throughout these different segments of these kingdoms that are eerily similar.  Statistically, it's almost impossible that this would happen over and over again unless somebody had an original document and had made copies of it and sent it out.  It's kind of like the telephone game.  Everything got a little distorted depending on where you went.
I guess I'm confused because we've got a calendar that's 2,000 years old, so we're 2019.
I don't understand.

More accurately, we have a calendar that's been dated.  We've been dated out 2,019 years since the birth of Christ, which... is a huge issue, you know, because some people don't even think he actually exists.  Yeah.  So we, that, I guess, would be a whole other conversation.

Yeah, but I don't know how we got those 2019 years, even if we're basing it on a mythological figure, if you believe that, or, you know, AD, after divinity, if we're marking the it didn't matter what we base the years we're marking on.  we're basing them on something and somebody has counted 2019 years.  uh.  so i don't understand.
even beyond that i guess my first question would be like what about like carbon dating?  and you know these other kinds of uh.
